alert.note: Alert for Lewis (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 12:05PM PST until March 02 at 9:54PM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Puyallup River Near Orting affecting Pierce County. Nisqually River Near National affecting Lewis and Pierce Counties. Cowlitz River At Randle affecting Lewis County. .A strong storm is coming in to western Washington with multiple factors that will produce high runoff and flooding. Heavy, prolonged rainfall will be coupled with some snow snow melt in low to mid elevations of the mountains from rising snow levels and strong warm and moist winds. This will drive some rivers above minor to major flooding. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO LATE WEDNESDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Cowlitz River At Randle. * WHEN...From this evening to late Wednesday evening. * IMPACTS...At 22.0 feet, the Cowlitz River will cause major flooding from the vicinity of Randle downstream through Riffe Lake...with dangerous inundation of many roads including US Highway 12...residential and commercial areas...and farms. Flooding will occur all along the river including headwaters... tributaries...and other streams within and near the Cowlitz River Basin. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 AM PST Monday the stage was 7.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this evening to a crest of 22.7 feet late tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 22.5 feet on 01/31/2003. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 800 PM PST.
